sources.title: Mr. Robinson Crusoe
sources.description: Taken from IMDB : While cruising the South Seas with friends aboard a sailing yacht, it is wagered that Steve can not survive on a desert isle without the accouterments of civilization. After accepting the wager, Steve and his dog swim ashore and begin to recreate their Park Avenue world by way of various Rube Goldberg type contraptions constructed from local materials. Meanwhile, on a nearby island, a young maiden flees her arranged wedding. She canoes to Steve's island for safety, whereupon she is dubbed "Saturday". Soon they are attacked by vengeful tribesmen from the neighboring island. Will Steve and Saturday survive?

sources.title: Mr. Robinson Crusoe
sources.description: adventure, comedy Information about this movie can be found on it's IMDB page.

sources.title: Mr. Robinson Crusoe (1932)
sources.description: Steve Drexel voluntarily strands himself on a deserted island on a bet. He intends to re-create civilization and carves a miniature city of 52nd Street and Park Avenue out of the jungle. Drexel is befriended by his dog, a native monkey, and a wild goat that is captured in one of his traps. He attempts to cultivate a native as his Man Friday from Robinson Crusoe, but fails as the native escape. Watch on RetroFlix:Â  https://retroflix.org/mr-robinson-crusoe-1932/

sources.title: Mr. Robinson Crusoe (1932) | Colorized Public Domain Island Adventure Comedy with Douglas Fairbanks
sources.description:
Mr. Robinson Crusoe (1932) is a pre-Code adventure comedy directed by A. Edward Sutherland and starring the legendary Douglas Fairbanks. Produced by United Artists, this inventive and spirited film reimagines Daniel Defoeâ€™s 18th-century survival tale for the modern era of the 1930s. Now digitally restored and colorized, this public domain gem brings back Fairbanksâ€™ unmatched athleticism, charisma, and optimism â€” all presented in vivid color and high-definition for todayâ€™s global audience.

Plot Summary:
Mr. Robinson Crusoe opens aboard a luxury yacht in the South Pacific, where wealthy sportsman Steve Drexel (Douglas Fairbanks) makes a daring bet with his friends. He claims he can live alone on a deserted island for an entire year â€” armed with nothing but his wits and determination. After leaping overboard, Drexel swims ashore to a lush tropical island and begins his experiment in self-reliance.

Ingeniously using natural resources, he builds a home, tools, and even a working radio. His charm and inventiveness transform the island into a functioning paradise, complete with makeshift furniture and creative gadgets. His solitude is broken when he meets a beautiful native woman, referred to as Saturday (Maria Alba), who becomes both his companion and partner in survival.

The film blends adventure, romance, and humor as Drexel faces wild animals, isolation, and unexpected visitors â€” including a group of pearl divers and hostile tribesmen. In typical Fairbanks fashion, the story is filled with daring stunts, graceful acrobatics, and unbreakable optimism. When Drexelâ€™s friends finally return, he proves that resourcefulness and imagination can triumph over luxury and dependence.

Cast and Crew:
â€¢ Director: A. Edward Sutherland
â€¢ Producer: Douglas Fairbanks
â€¢ Screenplay: Gene Towne and Graham Baker
â€¢ Cinematography: Oliver T. Marsh
â€¢ Editing: LeRoy Stone
â€¢ Production Company: United Artists
Starring:
â€¢ Douglas Fairbanks as Steve Drexel (Mr. Robinson Crusoe)
â€¢ Maria Alba as Saturday
â€¢ William Farnum as Mr. Blackwell
â€¢ Earle Brown as Two-Gun
â€¢ Robert W. Eddy as Tommy
â€¢ William Farnum Jr. as Crewman

Film Significance:
According to Wikipedia and IMDb, Mr. Robinson Crusoe marked one of the final starring roles of Douglas Fairbanks before his retirement. It captures his signature adventurous spirit in the transition from the silent era to sound cinema. The film showcases Fairbanksâ€™ unique combination of athletic physicality and light-hearted charm, hallmarks that made him a global icon.

Shot on location in the tropical islands near Tahiti, this early 1930s production stands out for its natural scenery, practical stunts, and inventive pre-Code humor. It offers a rare glimpse of Hollywood experimentation during a time of economic depression, providing escapist entertainment while reflecting optimism in self-reliance and ingenuity.

For modern audiences, this film serves as both a historical time capsule and an enduring lesson on creativity, courage, and independence â€” themes that remain universally relevant.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
This film is in the public domain, which means it is completely free of copyright restrictions and can be legally shared, viewed, studied, and preserved without limitation. Colorized Public Domain restores and enhances these historic works through careful digital cleaning, visual restoration, and colorization techniques. Our mission is to ensure that timeless classics like Mr. Robinson Crusoe remain available to a worldwide audience. By presenting them in color and modern quality, we make them more engaging and accessible to younger generations who might otherwise overlook black-and-white cinema. 

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
The original 1932 version was filmed in black and white, reflecting the limitations of early sound-era production. Through meticulous colorization, this edition revitalizes the island landscapes, ocean blues, and lush tropical vegetation â€” creating a more immersive visual experience, especially for modern TV screens, which dominate nearly 50 percent of Colorized Public Domainâ€™s viewership.

This restoration honors Douglas Fairbanksâ€™ adventurous legacy by giving new clarity and color depth to his stunts, expressions, and dynamic physicality. Viewers watching on large home screens can now appreciate the detailed craftsmanship and natural light that early cinematographers captured, making this colorized version both historically faithful and visually captivating.

sources.title: Mr. Robinson Crusoe (1932) DOUGLAS FAIRBANKS
sources.description:
Stars: Douglas Fairbanks, William Farnum and Earle Browne
Director: A. Edward Sutherland

Yachtsman Steve Drexel bets his friends that he can swim ashore on a remote south-seas island with nothing but a toothbrush and be 'living the life of Riley' when they return. With handmade implements the lighthearted, athletic Steve improbably builds a comfortable home with all amenities...and local fauna trained to help him! Meanwhile, a grass-skirted young lady flees an unwelcome wedding on a nearby island. Steve calls her Saturday, but what is he to do with her?

sources.title: Mr. Robinson Crusoe_Weirdness Bad Movie
sources.description: Public Access TV show "Weirdness Really Bad Movie" hosts public domain movies and ads clean comedy sketches enjoyable for the whole family. Today's film is Douglas Fairbanks second to last film, "Mr. Robinson Crusoe" from 1832.
